ADD THIS ADDITIONAL ITEM in this STEP:

Create a Kubernetes secret wadcert with the CA's certificate that signed the Active Directory's certificate using the following command:

         kubectl create secret generic wadcert --from-file=ssl/AD_CA.cer - n kube-system

config:
  expiry:
    idTokens: "10h"
  connectors:
  - type: ldap
    name: OpenLDAP
    id: ldap
    config:
      host: pv-windows-acti.cumulus.wrs.com:636
      rootCA: /etc/ssl/certs/adcert/AD_CA.cer
      insecureNoSSL: false
      insecureSkipVerify: false
      bindDN: cn=Administrator,cn=Users,dc=cumulus,dc=wrs,dc=com

      usernamePrompt: Username

        baseDN: ou=Users,ou=Titanium,dc=cumulus,dc=wrs,dc=com
        filter: "(objectClass=user)"
        username: sAMAccountName
        idAttr: sAMAccountName
        emailAttr: sAMAccountName
        nameAttr: displayName

Add a new subsection for "Using 'oidc-auth' command"

Using 'oidc-auth' command:
---------------------------

The oidc-auth CLI retrieves the ID token from Windows Active Directory using the OIDC client, and dex, and updates the Kubernetes credential for the user in the kubectl config file.

On controller-0, oidc-auth is installed as part of the base installation, and ready to use.

On a remote host with kubectl and helm client installed on the host, the following setup is required:
- Install the "Python Mechanize" module:
        # sudo pip2 install mechanize
- Get the oidc-auth script from the CENGEN Starlingx Mirror
   e.g.  http://mirror.starlingx.cengn.ca/mirror/starlingx/release/<RELEASE>/centos/outputs/oidcauth.tgz


Run oidc-auth script in order to authenticate and update user credentials in kubectl config file with the retrieved token.

$ oidc-auth -c <OAM ip address> -u testuser
Password:
Login succeeded.
Updating kubectl config ...
User testuser set.

Switch to the context for this user
$ kubectl config use-context testuser@mystxcluster

Run a kubectl command to ensure the TOKEN works:
$ kubectl get pods --all-namespaces

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message: Do we need to specify the acceptable return codes with a 'returns' attribute or is '0' the only acceptable return code?

I think we are ok as-is:

From the ip man page:
EXIT STATUS
       Exit status is 0 if command was successful, and 1 if there is a syntax error.  If an error was reported by the kernel exit status is 2.
The default is 0, I guess we can design it either way. You think we should design the other way or explicitly specify it?

You should be able to be explicit that this is only for ipv6 addresses.  In my opinion it would look cleaner like this:
[ $(ip -6 addr sh | grep -c inet6.*tentative) -eq 0 ]

Since the concern was regarding making the code extensible, i've added a dict comprehension. new headers (key: value) can be added by modifying the keys and values lists

Hi Rajat. Although you've already created a test test_update_base_image_ref [1] that passes base_image_ref as parameter, looks like the GlanceClientWrapper.call() method is mocked an will not cover these lines.

Maybe you could add a new test to method GlanceClientWrapper.call(), passing store_id and base_image_ref in order to cover these lines.

Bellow a unrefined example:

def test_call_with_additional_headers(self):
        glance_wrapper = glance.GlanceClientWrapper()
        fake_client = mock.Mock()
        self.mock_object(glance_wrapper, 'client', fake_client)

        glance_wrapper.call(self.context, 'method',
                            {},
                            store_id='xyz',
                            base_image_ref=123)

        self.assertDictEqual({
            'x-image-meta-store': 'xyz',
            'x-openstack-base-image-ref': 123},
            fake_client.http_client.additional_headers)


Another option is to change test_update_base_image_ref test to something similar to test_update_with_data[2], as it make real calls to 
 GlanceImageService.update() and GlanceClientWrapper.call() methods.

cinder/image/image_utils.py.message:
It seems unfortunate that this adds a requirement for any volume driver that calls upload_volume to pass in base_image_ref now.

Maybe we should have a volume_utils wrapper for upload_volume that lets drivers just pass in the volume ref rather than having to call get_base_image_ref() in every driver.

(It could handle both store_id and base_image_ref rather than us adding new fields to each driver for each change like this.)

Ideally, image_meta would be a place we could just pass this field straight from the API layer, but that doesn't work well since image_meta is intended for Glance's image metadata and not this field.
Sure, i can look into it in a followup

I wonder if you should add a comment here, something like:

NOTE: You probably want to use volume_utils.upload_volume(), not this function.

cinder/volume/volume_utils.py.message: Are you absolutely sure we can't get a KeyError here?  (End users can set image metadata via the os-set_image_metadata action, so I don't know that we can make any assumptions about what's in there.)
This comment doesn't really describe what this method is doing.
I'm not sure I understand why getattr is needed here.
I don't exactly remember (since i wrote this long time ago) why i explicitly used getattr here but the dot referencing works here so i don't mind changing this.

Sean's right. 'volume' is a cinder.objects.volume.Volume object, and 'glance_metadata' is defined on it.  And actually, if we needed getattr, it's already too late since we used the dot notation already at line 1261.  There's no guarantee that 'image_id' will be in the dict it gives you, though, so I think you still need to use get for that.

releasenotes/notes/upload-volume-to-mult.message:
We want to stress the Cinder side in the release note.  How about:

    This release includes support for Glance automatic image colocation.
    When a volume originally created from an image is uploaded to the
    Image service, Cinder passes Glance a reference to the original
    image.  Glance may use this information to colocate the new image data
    in the same image store(s) as the original image data.  Consult the
    Glance documentation for more information.

cinder/volume/drivers/solidfire.py.message: -1: This is logging twice the same information.
?: I assume this doesn't contain usernames or passwords, right?

This does not include cluster user and passwd but contains some data regarding isci connection. I changed to display just the account id.

Also, I've changed other debug logs in this method to display only the most significant fields.

-1: I don't think that is correct.

If I'm not mistaken for a failback you will get:

- Success: '' if the operation was successful.
- Error: The previous `active_backend_id` 

For failover:

- Success: The new backend id
- Error: The old backend id

Could you recheck, please?

You are correct. If failover fails, manager will catch the exception and call `failover_completed` using the previous active_backend_id (empty string when backend is not in failed-over state). 

I just wondering if calling `failover_completed` is really necessary when `failover` fails. As the driver is unaware of the failure, it will try to set to the backend he is already using.
Does this Fixme label still apply
Hi Jay, I removed the comment. Thanks!
Is the fixme still valid or should this comment be removed
does this fixme  label  still apply

releasenotes/notes/solidfire-active-acti.message: Would be good to clarify this by stating "replication" in here.
I think it's OK, since it's enabling A/A and adding support for replicated A/A in order to support the same features as in A/P.
Oh right, good point. The text confused me, so I think a little more precise wording would be better.
Then this line can be dropped since it's an odd addition on the end.

Thanks Sean and Gorka. I've added (including replication) to the first paragraph and deleted this one.

Do you folks think it's ok now or it's still missing a better explanation?

I agree, and if you really want to reflect that this is also supported you can always mention it on the first paragraph saying "support for Active/Active (including replication)" or something like that.

On the failure itself; it's due to the reason that one

Refer to the delete_configuration() method in nova/virt/libvirt/guest.py.

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message: Can we also add unit test for CPU AARCH64 host capabilities?
factoring this out into a private fucntion also makes sese give the amount of time this is checked.
ok so this is still need to have the correct behavior on x86

and then this reflect the arm default.
we might need to make this and "in" rathar then a "==" in the future as i suspect power and other architecutre might also eventually switch to uefi by default. for now this looks good to me.

Thanks!
Will keep this now and change in the future if necessary.

Just noting the exact cause of the error you quoted in the commit message; it's due to the requirement that when undefining a UEFI guest, you need to pass the flag: VIR_DOMAIN_UNDEFINE_NVRAM to the undefineFlags() API.  (This is taken care in the method called above: delete_configuration() in nova/virt/libvirt/guest.py.)
Yep, a separate method is clean.

ansible/network.yml.message: does reject imply reject('none') - falsey value?

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/boots.message: Please explain what testcase fails without this fix and now passes.

What is this change about? You don't use jinja templating delimiters such as {{ }} in ansible conditionals. This task is meant to fail the play if the default.yml is not the original file that comes with the playbook and the failing mandatory parameter is not in the host override file.

I always ignore this kinds of warnings. If you don't like it, we can replace the condition check with the following line:

```
when: item not in vars
```

I finally had the opportunity to rerun this task by commenting out a mandatory config parameter in default.yml. Upon closer inspection of the output, the playbook did fail but not at the right location. You are correct this task does not work as intended. Thanks!. Your change, however, results in a syntax warning which should not be ignored. 

The items in the list should then be presented as variable not value i.e.

with_items:
  - "{{ system_mode }}"
  - "{{ timezone }}"
  ...

By changing the definition of with_items, each time in the list is verified as variable instead of value and the result will be as intended. I would update the task as follows since Ansible evaluates the item in the list before it evaluates the "when" condition so the custom fail message is not displayed in this case which is not a big deal since Ansible fail message and the task name are comprehensive enough.

- name: Fail if any of the mandatory configuration is not defined
  debug:
    var: item
    verbosity: 4
  with_items:
    - "{{ system_mode }}"
    - "{{ timezone }}"
    ...

Considering follow playbook. We define var foo but not bar.
The expect behave is that ansible prints "foo is defined" for foo item but skip bar item. Because bar is not defined. But the actual behave is that neither foo nor bar is skipped.

```
root@ubuntu18:~# cat test1.yaml
- hosts: localhost
  vars:
    foo: 'value_foo'
  tasks:
    - debug: msg="{{ item }} is defined"
      when: item is defined
      with_items:
        - foo
        - bar
```

The commit message does not answer my question. Please explain what specific testcase fails before your change and now works after your change. You need to have a testcase to verify that your change works as expected.

This statement "you are testing item itself instead of the variables under "with_items" is in correct. With_items is a list of values, not variables; each of which is represented by the variable "item" when the list is iterated over.

As in python
my_list = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd']

for item in my_list:
  do_something(item)

You may want to read about Ansible conditionals and how with_items is used with when.

Please follow README.rst in this repo. You need Ansible 2.7 and higher as the bootstrap playbook requires networking related filters that only exist since 2.7.

If I understand correctly, we are testing if the variables under 'with_items' are defined, right?

Without this fix, you are testing item itself instead of the variables under 'with_items'.

If you add one undefined item, this task doesn't fail either. At least, this happens within my env with ansible 2.5.1
Please see the commit msg

No you shouldn't as warnings will eventually become errors.

The when: item not in vars would work only if the parameters are defined in the vars section of the playbook/block/tasks
Our playbooks contain many "source" commands that do not redirect the output. Exactly what bug are you fixing here?

Obviously, this is a potential bug.
There are two commands here. We are getting the output from one of them. Shouldn't we suppress the output of the other command?

We're sourcing info/conf/ini style files in all playbooks, not scripts. So I don't foresee these files will have the need to produce an output anytime soon. Let's leave the code as-is and re-evaluate if the need arises. If we do change, I'd like to make applicable change in all playbooks not just this file of bootstrap playbook.

The "source" command does not generate any output. We have many cases where multiple shell commands appear together like this and the output is not redirected. Again, explain why this change is necessary by giving me a testcase that is failing without your change and passes after your change.
It's not about 'source'. Please see commit msg

When it gets to here, the load has been deemed as StarlingX load and the /etc/build.info file must exist. As Bart already stated, sourcing an existing file does not generate any output so what would you like to suppress?

There is no failing case for now. But I would like to see  future.
I know that 'source /etc/build.info' doesn't generate any output for now. But from the view of design, we are supposed to redirect the output of 'source' command, because we are getting the output of 'echo' command.

Considering the following case:

For some reason, the content of /etc/build.info is updated, which generates some output. The register variable sw_version_result will contain the source command output as well, which is not expected.
Thanks for your explanation. As /etc/build.info is a ini style file, then it's ok to me to leave the code as it is.
This change is unnecessary and will not be accepted.

I had said that I agree source command has no output for now.
And you can also assume that there will be no output in the future.

But you introduce a limit here: any community developer should keep in mind that they can't add any content, which generates output, to /etc/build.info.

This would not work as it will fail for every item in this list since they are not in playbook/role/block vars section. Have you verified this change with the real bootstrap playbook instead of your test playbook?
As I know, this vars is not the same as the vars section. The vars here is a dict contains all variables(from extra-var, role defaults, inventory variables).

roles/ensure-pip/defaults/main.yaml.message:
This flag introduces a weird issue where we've hard coded applying its changes after python3 installs. This means `pip` will be python2 by default if this is set to True.

Maybe we can make this like the upstream interpreters list below?

  ensure_pip_from_packages_interpreters:
    - python3

By default but then can do:

  ensure_pip_from_package_interpreters:
    - python2
    - python3

If you want python3 pip by default and swap the ordering if you want python2 pip by default.

I think this is doable since all the packages that differentiate seems to use `python2` or `python3` in the package name.

Yup, after thinking on this I think the only places where my concern would be a real concern are if the system packages use an alternatives type system to manage what `pip` is. I am not aware of any platforms doing that.

> This flag introduces a weird issue where we've hard coded applying
 > its changes after python3 installs. This means `pip` will be
 > python2 by default if this is set to True.

If you're using packages, it will be up to the distribution as to what owns "/usr/bin/pip" though?

It's only in the case of running get-pip.py that the latest install will consider itself the owner of "/usr/local/bin/pip" leading to ambiguity over which version owns it.

I don't think there is an answer -- on things like debian i think it will be python2.  On things like centos8 I think there is no unversioned commands so the issue is moot.  On things like Fedora 31 (maybe 32) they've reclaimed "python" and namespace to be python3 as python2 doesn't exist.

So I don't think flipping the order in the packaged case makes a difference to the outcome.

roles/ensure-pip/tasks/Debian.yaml.message: Should all of the python3 and python2 installs check for ansible_python.version.major == 3/2 or is there a reason why we don't do that for some distros?

Distros where we just install python3 should have python3 available always.

The python2 check switch, as it is in this change, is my best guess on what platforms might have ansible_python as "2" so might need these libraries.  some platforms we support, such as later fedoras now, don't have python2.

I think this will need some tweaking over time as we figure things out.  Like TBH I'm not totally sure what gentoo is doing, but it runs on a very limited set of jobs anyway.

will add if we think it is needed. having this param helps to better describe the rate limit. e.g. 10/s vs 100 per 10s are not exactly the same. but from ncp point of view we're limited to 100/s from nsx, so at the moment we only care about period = 1.0. it can be easily exposed later.

I think we want some sort of log printout.
To avoid log spamming, maybe we should calculate average + total wait time and print once a period?
proposed log print once per 60s per endpoint, printing the avg wait time for the last 100 api calls.
One of these is not needed I think

I think here we can just use "if". The width of the window will never exceed self.max_rate. So when now - self.period > self.call_time[0], we just need to pop out the earliest timestamp. The width of the window will then be <= self.max_rate - 1. So correctness is guaranteed.

- yes, the width of the window will never exceed max_rate+1 normally. but i think it is more secure to not impose this assumption just in case something goes wrong / we plan to let some high priority api to bypass limit in some cases.
- for changing it to if -- technically correct if we always guarantee that call_time never exceed max_rate+1. but i still think the current approach is more straightforward and easier understandable. will change if others agrees.
nit: The earliest timestamp within the period is the first element in the window, so I think -self.max_rate is functionally the same as 0 here?
ok. changed this and the comment above

I feel that wait_time = self.call_time[-self.max_rate] + self.period - now is easier to understand.
For example, assume the earliest possible time to issue the next call is P. Thus,

P = self.call_time[-self.max_rate] + self.period
wait_time = P - now
correct but personally i still prefer the current one for the same reasons mentioned in the above comment.

Personally I prefer to see how long each API call waited.

(3) In https://review.opendev.org/#/c/718888/4/vmware_nsxlib/v3/cluster.py@670, change

        with endpoint.rate_limiter:
            yield EndpointConnection(endpoint, conn)

   to

nova/tests/unit/policies/base.py.message:
I'm wondering why does ignoring PolicyNotAuthorized work here? I would have thought we'd have to append to unauthorize_response when catching the exception, but yet the tests pass.

Could you please briefly explain why this is? Maybe worth a code comment.

yeah i should add a note here.

This is only for multi policy checks where second policy is with fatal=false but first not.  For example: flavor specs in flavor show API:  flavor extra spec policy is checked after get flavor policy. So any context failing on get flavor will raise the  PolicyNotAuthorized and in that case we do not have way to verify the flavor extra specs as context is already failed in first policy check. For that case, we catch the exception here and skip to add that response in unauthorize_response.
Ah, I see, thanks. Definitely would support adding a code comment here explaining this :)

cinder/volume/drivers/dell_emc/unity/uti.message:
Single line docstrings should just be one line of:

"""Summary message for docstring."""

If you want to document params and return values then it needs to be single line summary, blank line, then the rest of the details.

Take old_provision = thin into consideration.
`old_provision` and `new_provision` could have four possible values, `None`, `thin`, `thick` and `compressed`. Changing compression is enough in the retype between `None` and `compressed`, `thin` and `compressed`.
To keep return value consistency with other retype_new_xxx methods, it's better to use "return old != new" instead of only return True when old != new.

returns

If you are adding some docstring info, it would be good to add the whole documentation.

Hi Sean, the docstring for `return` could be either `returns` or `return` according to the sphinx document, http://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/domains.html:

    returns, return: Description of the return value.

Could you give some guidelines about when to use `returns` and when to use `return`? And the default behavior in pycharm for generating rst docstring is using `return`. I didn't find a way to change it. Do you know any tips about configuring pycharm to use `returns`?

Thank you!

hmm. the only thing sushy doesn't support is password... sad.. please disregard my comment

instead of sushy_emulator, that comes from upstream, we can actually use the following py file [1]
it behaves exactly the same way as sushy_emulator, but if the following env variables SUSHY_EMULATOR_USERNAME SUSHY_EMULATOR_PASSWORD, it will check username and password.

So we can get back to the plan with revert of 'reverse-proxy' commit if we start using this python file and run it twice: for http and https.

[1]
import os
import re
import sys
from sushy_tools.emulator.main import app, main

username = None
password = None

@app.before_request
def before_request_func():
    from flask import request, abort
    if not username is None:
        if request.authorization is None:
            abort(403)
        r_username = request.authorization.get("username")
        r_password = request.authorization.get("password")
        if r_username is None or r_username != username or \
                r_password is None or r_password != password:
            abort(403)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    sys.argv[0] = re.sub(r'(-script\.pyw?|\.exe)?$', '', sys.argv[0])
    username = os.environ.get("SUSHY_EMULATOR_USERNAME")
    password = os.environ.get("SUSHY_EMULATOR_PASSWORD")
    sys.exit(main())

The group does not have to start with '_' if it is a string

AccessInfoV3 instance cant be serialized by JSON Serializer, but we can easily extract init arguments from the instance and just re-instantiate it during de-serialization. I assume, it is the shortest and clearest variant how we can implement it

doc/source/configuration/cert_config.rst.message: update the certificate with a certificate signed by a certificate authority
For ssl_ca certificate, no private key is required in the pem file. Actually there shouldn't be any private keys in the file.

change to:

where <ca-certs.pem> == a PEM file containing one or more CA Certificates to add to the list of trusted CAs of the system.
I would simply remove this NOTE

This is no longer true for ssl_ca certificates. For ssl_ca certificate, the install command is to add the certificates in the pem file to the system's trusted CA certificate list. If some certs in the pem file are already installed in the system, the command does nothing to them. It doesn't replace any of the installed certificates. system certificate-uninstall can be used to remove a CA certificate from the system's trusted CA cert list. system certificate-install and certificate-uninstall are to be used to update existing trusted CA cert list.

I think the system certificate-uninstall is missing from the document. Please check my email to the discussion list, it contains details about this command.

ADD the following to the Platform Trusted CAs info
----

* To list the trusted CAs for the StarlingX platform:
        system certificate-list

        where all entries with certtype = ssl_ca are Trusted CA Certificates

* To remove from the list of trusted CAs for the StarlingX platform:
        system certificate-uninstall -m ssl_ca <UUID>

        where <UUID> is the UUID of the ssl_ca certtype to be removed.
                                 Use 'system certificate-list' to determine the UUUID.

ansible/roles/elasticsearch/tasks/upgrad.message: Am I correct that this is a paid feature in 5.x? What does the free version of ES 5.x do when you call this?

Ah yes, you are correct. It's also only in paid versions of 6.x+, so we can safely delete it. I had just copied it from the prior release.

FYI in 5.x, this call returns a 400. Adding `status_code: [200, 400]` would make it work for 5.x and 6.x, but as you point out, we can simply remove. Will update.

I also had that thought, and wondered why it was never in place. I think, though, it's not needed because KA currently sets it as a "transient" setting, meaning it will be cleared upon restart. Since the play will ultimately do a full reboot of the ES cluster, I think it's fine to keep it as a transient setting for simplicity.

docker/base/elasticsearch.repo.message:
Since ES 6.3 x-pack is bundled in and ES is released under the Elastic licence [1]. We can continue to use the Apache licensed version without x-pack by using the oss- packages, eg:

`baseurl=https://artifacts.elastic.co/packages/oss-6.x/yum`

Unless someone has gone through the Elastic license and thinks it is OK to use, I think we should stick with Apache.
